Comment: Knowingly polluting a river could cause others to become sick, which would violate the NAP. Looking through the lens of libertarianism, that would be against the tenets of the party.  As for _who_ should be keeping your neighbors out of your business, the answer is quite clear. There is a need for enforcement in every civilized country. Even in a home, you'll see this play out. A child steals money from their sibling to buy something they want. Who enforces the rules? A parental figure. But where an authoritarian figure may look to physical reprimands or yelling (is it any wonder why Republicans lean towards spanking as an acceptable punishment?), I think we'd both agree that a more open minded individual would take a less invasive and aggressive approach.  I apply the same mindset to 'the state.' Should we have facial recognition cameras on every corner? No.  Should we try to anticipate _who_ will commit a crime like Palantir seems to be aiming for? No.  Should we still entertain the death penalty? No.  There is a solid case for enforcement but it quickly gets out of hand and unconstitutional. Look at what is happening right now with deportations. Look at what has happened in the last with ICE, the DEA, and ATF. There is always overreach. Does that mean that they are entirely bad? No. But there is no enforcement for the enforcement, and that is dangerous for the liberty of all.  If a right has to be *given,* it is not a right.
